newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss stocks slump more than three percent.
newsitem.headline: Swiss stocks slump more than three percent.

text.p: Swiss shares ended with a slump of more than three percent on Wall Street's tumble in recent days and a shaky outlook.
"Some of the players were obviously taken by surprise," one dealer said, adding some investors had positioned themselves for a further rise after last week's recovery of Swiss shares.
"What's more, the dollar's recent fall added pressure on Swiss exporters," he said.
One trader added the prospects looked dim given a weakness of the U.S. long bond and possible further Wall Street losses.
The blue-chip Swiss Market Index (SMI) fell 157.5 points, or 3.38 percent, to 4,501.7, touching a low at 4,482.2 points.
The all-share Swiss Performance Index (SPI) ended down 90.02 points, or 3.06 percent, at 2,856.23.
One dealer said volume was relatively high, adding there was little bargain hunting despite the correction.
"People are nervous, also because we're on daylight savings time now in Europe, so Wall Street and U.S. economic data come in later than usual," he noted.
Most blue chips saw marked losses. Nestle, which led the active list, gave up 64 francs to 1,621 and Roche slid to 11,925 francs.
Among financials, recent high-flyer CS Group was one of the bigger losers. The shares ended down 9.50 francs to 163.25.

Insurer Zurich slid 16.50 francs to 436.50. A rumour that Zurich was interested in German insurer Victoria had no impact, a dealer said. A Zurich spokeswoman said the compnay did not comment on rumors as a matter of principle. Victoria's major shareholder Munich Re said it will keep its stake in Victoria.
ABB, Sulzer, Adecco performed better than the market but also ended in negative terrain.
